{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3399755,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T06:51:07.007Z","cooked":"

@ClayTownR , I‚Äôve been following your awesome tutorial.

Lantern Gear Design Tutorial CAD
It seems as though my claim to fame is my collection of power transmission tutorials. I was recently asked for some help on designing lantern gears, which are a special type of gear which are generally easier to fabricate than involute gears, but which aren‚Äôt a huge loss on strength and efficiency. Outline The idea behind a lantern gear is probably older than involute gears: simply let your pinion be a circle of pins, and then have that turn a plate with cutouts for those pins. However, this m‚Ä¶

so when you place your pinion, what would be the center to center distance between the pinion and gear be? is it (D_g/ 2) + (D_p/2)? do I add any offset for clearance?

does this look ok to you?

Capture 2788√ó82 13.3 KB

Capture1397√ó699 52.7 KB

Thank you

In my demonstration I used \frac{1}{2}(D_g + D_p). You can definitely add more to that if you want (for instance, if you have a bad tolerance stackup and want to prevent interference). The main tradeoff is that depthing further will reduce the likelihood of binding at the cost of increased slop. If you want to be ‚Äúperfect‚Äù, I suggest making the gear and pinion first and then empirically finding a good depthing.

I like that approach. I was more nervous about the gear teeth surface finish/chatter, depending how I would cut this. Thanks again.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T16:09:16.296Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":551,"readers_count":550,"score":110.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28741,"username":"ClayTownR","name":"Clayton Ramsey","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/claytownr/{size}/158381_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399835,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T16:30:40.315Z","cooked":"

Really interested to hear from anyone who has used this for FRC. What is the best use case? There‚Äôs a lot of good opportunities for machinability and printability in the design, but are there situations where this design is genuinely better than than a COTS gearing option or a 10DP machinable profile?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T16:30:40.315Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":521,"readers_count":520,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Eric Bergquist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23148,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/5","custom_user_title":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399864,"name":"Travis Norris","username":"TNorris","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tnorris/{size}/203666_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T17:42:16.657Z","cooked":"

Both 1690 and 1678 used something similar this year for their shooter angles. 125 as well used a printed version

Pulling from a post in the Citrus thread:

Citrus Circuits 2024 Code, CAD, and Strategy Release

The main goal for sector gear was to minimize backlash as much as possible. Both the 3D printed gear and the pinion system have multiple points of contact, which effectively helped to reach that goal.

We abandoned 3D Printed design due to repeated failures at competition. At Silicon Valley and Sacramento, we encountered issues with skipping towards the end. We tried to increase the strength of the print in different ways, but it ultimately did not work. We then tried 971‚Äôs generator from 2017 and got a profile that worked great for the pinion system.

A little bit more on team‚Äôs using them historically here

The NUTRONs, 2024 Code and CAD Release","clicks":16},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/citrus-circuits-2024-code-cad-and-strategy-release/466792/68","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Citrus Circuits 2024 Code, CAD, and Strategy Release","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23148,"username":"kitare102","name":"Eric Bergquist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39882,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Coach - FRC 2423 | NEMC Planning Committee"},"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/6","custom_user_title":"Head Coach - FRC 2423 | NEMC Planning Committee","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399878,"name":"Ardiano Works","username":"MSU2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T18:38:13.059Z","cooked":"

To me, the biggest advantage is the ability to design the drive train that fits your real estate, especially when you don‚Äôt need full rotation, this gear sector can be packaged nicely.

Another advantage is reducing backlash IF you can make the gear precisely. The pinion is straight forward to make. Holes pattern with press fit dowel pin.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T18:38:13.059Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":415,"readers_count":414,"score":118.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Ardiano Works","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":23148,"username":"kitare102","name":"Eric Bergquist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57747,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399893,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T19:26:54.493Z","cooked":"
Cutting Gears out of Plastics Manufacturing
The provenance of this in FRC afaik is Nexen roller gears on radar systems I worked on > 2016 973 offseason meme bot > 971 2017 > 3476 2019 Its pretty neat, we did it to enable cutting the driven gear more easily on a router. Now that there are so many viable options to laser/water or print the gear classic gears are likely the better solution. You also have a much larger minimum pinion size due to the pin rollers, especially if you put them in bearings or bushings. Which depending on your ra‚Ä¶

I would tend to agree with Adam‚Äôs conclusions in this post (thanks @TNorris for the thread link), and appreciate his note about the relative backlash between the lantern and involute systems he evaluated. Also, having used Nexen gearing before, they have roller pins instead of rigid pins. With rigid pins, I would expect greater backlash due to the required extra slop needed for low friction operation.

To your point about custom sector gears for arm packaging, it seems like at this point just using a 10DP profile that can be cut on a router alongside a COTS 10DP pinion gear is the better option for FRC. I loved the integrated 10DP sector gear that 2491 NoMythic used for their shooter this year.

However, the lantern gear is certainly a valid design strategy and something that would provide a great challenge for a mid-level manufacturing team.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T19:26:54.493Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":406,"readers_count":405,"score":121.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Eric Bergquist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/cutting-gears-out-of-plastics/442969/21","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Cutting Gears out of Plastics","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57747,"username":"MSU2000","name":"Ardiano Works","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/msu2000/{size}/190139_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23148,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/8","custom_user_title":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399898,"name":"Bruce Newendorp","username":"Bruce_Newendorp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/c89c15/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T19:37:14.354Z","cooked":"

We used a lantern gear to adjust our shooter hood angle in 2021. The gear sector is part of a # 35 chain sprocket profile. A 5 mm dowel pin fits very well into the root of the sprocket profile. The dowel pins are spaced the same as # 35 chain and pressed into 3D printed pinion sides. It‚Äôs driven by a snowblower motor with a pair of gears driving an analog position sensor.

image1625√ó1311 406 KB

Can you not just use a roller chain sprocket profile for these? For instance, 35 (3/8") pitch sprockets should fit well with 5mm dowels, if I remember correctly, and there are already sprocket generator scripts available.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T20:55:12.702Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":321,"readers_count":320,"score":79.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399930,"name":"Bruce Newendorp","username":"Bruce_Newendorp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/c89c15/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T21:07:29.793Z","cooked":"

Yes, the design used a sprocket profile generator in Onshape. It was # 35, not 25.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2024-06-18T21:07:29.793Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":303,"readers_count":302,"score":80.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":467735,"topic_slug":"lantern-gear-design-revisit","display_username":"Bruce Newendorp","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3500,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/lantern-gear-design-revisit/467735/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3399955,"name":"Matt Golman","username":"BordomBeThyName","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png","created_at":"2024-06-18T22:44:19.740Z","cooked":"

ANSI 35 chain has 0.200" rollers, and 5mm is about 0.197" so that combo should work well. I haven‚Äôt tried it before, but I recently learned that ISO 06B chain has the same pitch, but with 0.250" rollers, so an 06B sprocket with 1/4" dowels should work well too.

kitare102:

With rigid pins, I would expect greater backlash due to the required extra slop needed for low friction operation.

Generally if you are doing this style of gearing you don‚Äôt care much about the friction. If you are running rigid pins you can make it smaller which gives more mechanical advantage. For our shooter angle we didn‚Äôt add any slop, it was full contact and all we did to mitigate the contact friction/wear was 7075 teeth and grease with Molybdenum Disulphide to keep it moving.

Sprockets and lantern gears have very different curves if calculated optimally.

With a sprocket, you typically have several pins fully in the root of the teeth at all times, so the tooth profile isn‚Äôt all that important, as there will always be fully seated pins. I model sprocket teeth such that a link can have 1 pin fully seated in the root, and the other pin is free to move fully into or out of the root, but you could probably make more complex sprocket teeth that engage with the pins for longer in a typical chain setup.

With lantern gears there are only a few pins engaged with the teeth and there is only a pin fully engaged with the root momentarily once per tooth of rotation. Because you almost never have a pin fully engaged with the root, it becomes critical to use the proper tooth profile if low backlash is required, and the only practical way to do that is with equation driven curves.

Stealing @MSU2000 ‚Äôs picture from above. Notice that with the sprocket profile only the green pin is engaging the sprocket, the red pins are floating between 2 teeth but not actually touching. If you were to turn the pinion half a tooth there would be significant backlash. (I‚Äôm on my phone or I‚Äôd get a decent picture of a proper lantern gear profile)
